title: Chief minister
text:
A chief minister is an <a href="Election">elected</a> or appointed <a href="head%20of%20government">head of government</a> of – in most instances – a <a href="sub-national%20entity">sub-national entity</a>, for instance an administrative subdivision or federal constituent entity. Examples include a <a href="Federated%20state">state</a> (and sometimes a <a href="union%20territory">union territory</a>) in <a href="India">India</a>; a territory of <a href="Australia">Australia</a>; a province of <a href="Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> or <a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>; a <a href="Provinces%20of%20Nepal">federal province</a> in <a href="Nepal">Nepal</a>; an <a href="Autonomous%20regions%20of%20the%20Philippines">autonomous region</a> of Philippines; or a <a href="British%20Overseas%20Territory">British Overseas Territory</a> that has attained self-governance. It is also used as the English version of the title given to the heads of <a href="government">government</a>s of the <a href="Malay%20states">Malay states</a> without a <a href="monarchy">monarchy</a>.
The title is also used in the <a href="Crown%20dependencies">Crown dependencies</a> of the <a href="Isle%20of%20Man">Isle of Man</a> (since 1986), in <a href="Guernsey">Guernsey</a> (since 2004), and in <a href="Jersey">Jersey</a> (since 2005).
In 2018 <a href="Sierra%20Leone">Sierra Leone</a>, a <a href="presidential%20republic">presidential republic</a>, created the role of an appointed Chief Minister, which is similar to a <a href="Prime%20minister">Prime Minister</a> in a <a href="semi-presidential%20system">semi-presidential system</a>. Before that, only <a href="Milton%20Margai">Milton Margai</a> had the same position between 1954 and 1958.
Meaning and role.
The title has a similar construction and role as a <a href="prime%20minister">prime minister</a>, <a href="first%20minister">first minister</a> or <a href="minister-president">minister-president</a> but usually with a lower rank. The role has context within the <a href="Westminster%20system">Westminster system</a> of government where a constitutional <a href="head%20of%20state">head of state</a> (usually sub-national) is <a href="Advice%20%28constitutional%29">advised</a> by <a href="Minister%20%28government%29">ministers</a> who usually head executive government departments (<a href="Ministry%20%28government%20department%29">ministries</a>). A chief minister is understood to be "first among equals". They would be the chief adviser to the nominal head of their state, the <a href="chairman">chair</a> of <a href="Cabinet%20%28government%29">cabinet</a> and leader of the main governing <a href="political%20party">political party</a> in the <a href="legislature">legislature</a>.
